This study introduces an innovative methodology that integrates Inverse Conformable Artificial Neural Networks (CANNi) with Genetic Algorithms (GA) or Particle Swarm Optimization (PSO) to optimize thermal comfort in buildings. Emphasizing the efficacy of conformable transfer functions within CANNi, the research relies on a comprehensive dataset to forecast heat transfer across diverse climates. Notably, the methodology stands out for its meticulous model selection process, employing slope-intercept tests to ensure robust predictability (99%) and strong correlation between input and output variables. The selected model exhibits an optimal equilibrium between predictive precision and computational efficiency, reaching an R-value of 0.9992 with low RMSE (0.0078) and MAPE (2.1099). Such performance enables precise calibration of Radiant Floor Heating Systems (RFH) for enhanced comfort and marks a significant stride toward bolstering energy efficiency and sustainability within the construction sector. These findings advocate for more efficient utilization of energy resources in buildings, adeptly accommodating climatic fluctuations and enhancing the inhabitants’ quality of life. Keywords Inverse conformable artificial neuronal networks Genetic algorithms Heat transfer Radiant floor Particle swarm optimization Data availability Data will be made available on request. Natural gas accounts for over 23 % of global electricity generation [2], highlighting a significant dependency that, in the wake of recent geopolitical conflicts, has triggered a resurgence in coal usage within the power sector. This reactive shift has addressed immediate energy requirements and contributed to increased greenhouse gas emissions, further aggravating the environmental challenges confronting our world [3,4]. The residential sector ranks as the second-largest consumer of electricity, with air conditioning playing a crucial role, representing 57 % of the total consumption [5]. The distribution of energy usage for heating and cooling stands at 3.8 % and 53.4 %, respectively [6], highlighting a substantial demand for regulating indoor temperatures. Climate change has increased the need for space conditioning, and current projections do not anticipate reversing this trend [7–9]. This situation results in elevated operational costs and environmental impact, necessitating a comprehensive reassessment of the technologies and approaches employed for residential thermal management. Radiant Floor Heating systems (RFH) are becoming a promising choice among emerging alternatives due to their energy efficiency and capacity to deliver thermal comfort. These systems utilize the floor as a thermal source and commonly involve circulating water through tubing embedded in the floor structure [10]. To optimize the design of RFH, it's essential to understand how efficiently heat is transferred across surfaces within these systems. The heat flux is crucial in quantifying how effectively heat is transferred through different mediums. This parameter is essential for designing efficient thermal systems and predicting temperature distributions in various industrial processes and physical systems. It helps engineers and designers make informed decisions about improving such systems' performance. The heat flux of RFH can be influenced by various factors, including solar radiation, heat supply, room location, outside temperature, and the surrounding heating conditions [11,12]. Each of these elements has the potential to impact the efficiency with which the radiant floor system manages heat. It is crucial to comprehensively assess these factors to optimize system performance and effectively address energy and environmental challenges. Over the years, numerous studies have been conducted to evaluate the heat transfer capacity of RFH systems and to develop methods to improve it. However, a closer look reveals that, although these studies have made significant contributions, they also present methodological limitations that leave room for improvement. For example, Jing et al. [13] developed numerical models for different radiant heating structures using a microtube array. Although these models provided valuable information about the temperature distribution and heat transfer process, their limited experimental approach leaves questions about their applicability to different RFH configurations. Xu et al. [14] used the finite volume method to investigate heat flux involving phase change, optimizing the water supply temperature and establishing guidelines for surface temperature variation. Although this work contributes to the design of efficient RFH systems in intermittent mode, its focus on optimizing a single parameter may limit its applicability in more complex scenarios where multiple variables interact simultaneously. Wang et al. [15] proposed a calculation model for determining total heat flux ( q t ) in RFH. While the model showed superior performance compared to the standard ISO formula, significantly reducing standard deviations and improving the accuracy of q t calculations, its dependence on temperature variations along specific parameters raises questions about its robustness under changing conditions. The introduction of artificial neural networks (ANNs) in the field of heat flux has opened new possibilities for improving prediction accuracy. Acikgoz et al. [16] developed an ANN model for predicting heat transfer coefficients in a radiant floor system using a backpropagation architecture with the TANSIG transfer function. This model achieved high accuracy in predicting heat flux in RFH, with a correlation coefficient of 0.99955. However, the relatively simple structure of the model may not fully capture the complex thermal interactions in more advanced RFH. Verma et al. [17] proposed an ANN model to predict heat flow in an underfloor heating and cooling (RHC) system. Despite its high accuracy, with an R2 of 0.9984 and an MSE of 0.00055, the exclusive use of conventional transfer functions such as TANSIG and Purelin could limit its generalizability to unknown contexts, more modern, and flexible functions. The literature on mathematical modeling and deep learning highlights the importance of selecting optimal transfer functions. While TANSIG has been commonly used, other options, such as LOGSIG, SOFTPLUS, SWISH, and ELU, are gaining relevance to address specific challenges such as gradient degradation, improved model convergence, and generalization to various applications. SOFTPLUS is a smoothing of ReLU, defined as f x = I n 1 + e - x , which offers numerical stability. SWISH is defined as f x = x 1 + e - β x , a flexible activation that improves convergence. ELU (Exponential Linear Unit) is defined as f x = x , α ∙ e - x - 1 , x ≥ 0 , x < 0 . accelerating convergence and reducing gradient saturation. The choice of transfer function can substantially impact the performance of neural networks in various applications [18–21]. However, these investigations do not adequately address the implementation of new conformable functions derived from fractional calculus, which can offer advantages in terms of model simplification and robustness to noise. Solís-Pérez et al. [22] proposed a conformable artificial neural network (CANN) based on TANSIG and Khalil's conformable exponential function [23]. Although these models showed their ability to achieve high correlation coefficients in different experimental scenarios, their applicability in complex RFH systems has not yet been fully explored. Control-oriented optimization systems, such as Inverse Artificial Neural Networks (ANNi), have proven to be valuable tools for improving the efficiency of thermal systems. Garcia-Morales et al. [24] applied an ANNi model to control the outlet temperature in a double-tube heat exchanger, achieving superior benchmark tracking with a low RMSE of 0.2025. However, this approach has yet to be tested in more dynamic and complex applications such as RFH systems. Ajbar et al. [25] improved the thermal efficiency of a parabolic trough using ANNi in combination with genetic algorithms (GA) and particle swarm optimization (PSO). This approach proved to be effective, achieving a high correlation coefficient of 0.9511 and a low MSE of 0.0193. However, the integration of these techniques in the context of RFH systems remains an underexplored area, highlighting the need for further research. The integration of CANN with ANNi gives rise to a promising area, leading to the development of inverse conformable artificial neural networks (CANNi). This combination leverages the strengths of both approaches: CANN excels at capturing complex data relationships and is robust to noise, while ANNi models systems in reverse, transforming outputs into inputs. This integration holds great potential for addressing various application problems, offering a powerful and versatile approach. This article explores the application of CANNi as a novel approach to enhancing and expediting prediction models in heat flux in RFH. The methodology involves utilizing ANN with diverse activation functions, including traditional ones like LOGSIG and TANSIG, and modern functions like SOFTPLUS, SWISH, and ELU, along with their conformable counterparts. The objective is to capture the intricate data relationships in the construction effectively. Additionally, the study introduces the concept of Control-Oriented Optimization Systems, specifically CANNi, which leverage deep CANN learning for system control. This innovative approach aims to optimize the performance of RFH and enhance their energy efficiency. This study enhances and refines a previously established model for calculating the heat flux in RFH. Investigate how the use of CANNi can optimize and control the model. The primary contributions of this research are as follows: • Pioneering application of CANNi in the optimization of RFH systems, improving parameter prediction. • Optimization and simplification of the heat flux prediction model for RFH. • Control of the heat flux prediction model for RFH through an inversion approach. • Innovation in data management, adapting to changing conditions in real environments. 2 Experimental Setup Fig. 1 illustrates a radiant floor system that is the subject of investigation in this study. This system comprises four structural layers: a top cover layer, a screed coat, a filler layer, an insulation layer, and a heat exchanger pipe. Several vital operational characteristics define the radiant system's behavior, including the mass flow rate ( m f ), heat resistance ( R s ), mean temperature of heat transfer fluid ( T wm ) circulating inside the radiant tube, and the operative temperature ( T op ). Finally, the radiant system's heat flux ( q t ) corresponding to the specified operational parameters is selected as a performance output measure. These key variables, also illustrated in Fig. 1, play a crucial role in determining the performance of the system. It is important to note that Fig. 1 is a schematic representation of a typical RFH system. The data utilized in this study were not generated through simulations but were instead compiled and reported by Verma et al. [17], who collected experimental data from various published studies that conducted real-world experiments. Table 1 presents the system parameters and operating ranges derived from the literature [17]. On the other hand, Table 2 presents a comparison of the operational ranges across studies referenced in the literature, as outlined in source [17]. 3 Methodology As previously mentioned, ANN is a framework of interconnected neurons capable of processing and transmitting information to generate specific responses. Modeling with ANN involves four primary stages: data preprocessing, network architecture design, network training, and network performance analysis. Network architecture design, training, and performance analysis are vital components. Fig. 2 provides a visual representation of the sequence of these steps. 3.1 Preprocessing Data cleaning involves the elimination of inaccurate, duplicated, or incomplete data. Data normalization converts numerical attributes to a standardized scale, preventing variables with higher magnitudes from overshadowing those with lower magnitudes during training. Eq. (1) illustrates one frequently used data normalization method [31]. (1) x n = y max - y min ∗ x exp - x min x max - x min + y min x n is the normalized variable, x exp is the experimental variable to be normalized, x min and x max are the minimum and maximum of the input variable, and y min and y max represent the normalization range. Normalization was applied to both input and output variables, scaling them to fall within the range of 0.1 to 0.9, as defined in Eq. (1). This standardization procedure was essential for ensuring uniformity in the data and easing the training process of the ANN. Data partitioning involves splitting the dataset into subsets, typically called the training, validation, and testing sets. The training set is employed to fine-tune the parameters of the ANN using an optimization algorithm. The testing set selects the best model from several candidates based on criteria like the correlation coefficient (R). The testing set is crucial for estimating the real-world performance of the chosen model when applied to new data. This deliberate division strategy enables us to train the model, optimize its parameters, and assess its performance on unseen data, ensuring its robustness and accuracy [32]. After data preprocessing, the ANN's modeling involves determining the optimal combination of the number of layers, the number of neurons in each layer, and the transfer functions to be employed. This phase is determined empirically, iterating until an appropriate architecture is achieved. The selection of the architecture significantly impacts the model's capacity to learn and generalize from the data. 3.2 ANN architecture The general architecture of an ANN is typically divided into three sections: the input layer, the hidden layers, and the output layer. The input layer consists of neurons and variables that represent the input data. Its primary function is to capture and transmit the input data to subsequent layers. The hidden layer contains a variable number of neurons, determined through an iterative process guided by model performance. Within a neuron in the hidden neural network layer, a linear combination of the inputs weighted by their respective weights is computed, resulting in a summation. This sum is subsequently processed through a nonlinear transfer function to capture the intricate relationships between the input and output variables [33]. In the hidden layer, transfer functions produce nonlinear transformations, enabling them to address high-complexity problems effectively. Transfer functions play a crucial role in the processing and transmission of information across the layers of an ANN, thereby influencing its performance [34]. Two classical functions, LOGSIG (logarithmic sigmoid) and TANSIG (hyperbolic tangent sigmoid), have been prevalent in the literature due to their desirable properties, including their capacity to introduce nonlinearities into the model [25]. In the continuous pursuit of enhancing performance and training stability, alternative functions like SOFTPLUS, SWISH, and ELU have emerged. These functions are precious for regression or multi-class classification problems as they can effectively represent positive and negative values. While they have received comparatively less attention, they have demonstrated effectiveness in specific contexts by offering more stable gradients and enhancing convergence in deep training [35–42]. 3.3 Conformable transfer functions Incorporating fractional calculus into transfer functions has recently led to significant enhancements in the performance and simplification of predictive models. While the concept of implementing fractional calculus had been considered previously, it wasn't until Khalil introduced his definition of fractional derivative [43] that this implementation became viable. Consequently, this definition of fractional calculus satisfies the fundamental properties of differentiation, including the derivative of a constant, the product rule, the quotient rule, and the chain rule. This paves the way for the potential generalization of the calculation to non-integer orders. This emphasis led to the creation of conformable transfer functions, which incorporate characteristics of fractal calculus into traditional transfer functions [22]. Conformable functions like CLOGSIG, CTANSIG, CSOFTPLUS, CSWISH, and CELU offer potential advantages over their conventional counterparts, especially regarding adaptability and performance in specific contexts. Various factors drive the selection criteria for their application. Fig. 3 illustrates the behavior of conformable transfer functions when the parameters λ and ξ are arbitrarily chosen. The conventional transfer functions are obtained when λ = 1 and ξ = 1. The output layer represents the variable response. The configuration of this layer depends on the nature of the problem at hand. Suppose the problem is regression, which aims to predict a continuous value. In that case, the output layer may consist of a single neuron that employs a linear or identity function to generate the constant prediction. Finally, Eq. (2) shows the objective function of the ANN with one hidden layer. Given the nonlinear characteristics of neural networks and the complexity of the model, employing rigorous validation techniques is of utmost importance. The Slope-Intercept test assesses the agreement between model predictions and observed values. In an ideal scenario, the projections would closely follow a 1:1 relationship with the actual values, resulting in a slope ( m ) near 1 and an intercept ( b ) is near 0. However, it's unusual for a model to achieve these ideal values precisely in practice. Therefore, an approach is taken by approximating one parameter above and one parameter below the slope and the intercept. In this way, a clear view of the model's bias and accuracy is obtained [44]. Statistical metrics are quantitative measures used to assess the extent of disparity between actual and predicted values. Numerous statistical metrics are available for evaluating the performance of ANNs, each with its strengths and limitations. Below, we will describe some of these metrics: The correlation coefficient (R) is a metric that assesses the linear relationship between two continuous variables [45]. The Root Mean Square Error (RMSE) offers an absolute measure of the discrepancy between predictions and actual values. The Mean Absolute Percentage Error (MAPE) computes the average error of a model using absolute value measurements, providing a notable advantage in terms of interpretability compared to other metrics [46]. 3.5 Control strategy with ANNi Developing ANN models represents a powerful approach for optimizing various aspects such as time, cost, and error in representing complex phenomena using operational variables. ANNi models introduce an innovative inversion approach by transforming target variables into model inputs. This inversion enables the model to receive the target variables and generate the operational variables necessary to achieve that outcome. By leveraging ANNi models, researchers can enhance their ability to manipulate and control systems efficiently to achieve specific desired outcomes [24,25,47–49]. To achieve the optimal application of ANNi models, it's essential to consider the following key points: • Develop an equation that faithfully represents the underlying phenomenon. • Identify and uphold context-specific variables throughout the analysis. • Strategize model inversion. • Optimize output variables for enhanced performance and accuracy. • Model simulation through scenario generation. We start with meticulously formulating the equation to delineate the captivating phenomenon. This equation is obtained by embedding the transfer function, weights, and biases acquired during CANN training into the objective function Eq. (2). This establishes a solid foundation for the model, enabling a precise representation of the underlying dynamics. Next, it's crucial to identify and keep constant context-specific variables, which, although important, need to be more generalizable. This simplifies the analysis without compromising the validity of the focus. This strategy directs optimization efforts toward manipulable operational factors critical for system improvement. The investment process starts by setting the model's equation to zero concerning the manipulable operating variables, a crucial step in identifying optimal operating points. This procedure enables direct and effective intervention in these variables, guiding them toward desired optimization goals. Subsequently, these and the objective variables are separated from the general model and become inputs in the new ANNi model. This approach fosters a clear and organized structure, streamlining simulations and simplifying optimization tasks. During the optimization phase, genetic algorithms (GA) and Particle Swam Optimization (PSO) are employed due to their remarkable capacity to navigate complex search spaces and converge to optimal solutions [50–55]. GA simulates the evolution of living organisms, where more fit individuals dominate over less fit ones, resembling biological evolution mechanisms such as natural selection, crossover, and mutation [56]. PSO draws inspiration from the collective behavior of birds or pelicans. Its objective is to discover the optimal solution for a problem by continuously adjusting the positions and velocities of particles within an array [57]. The inspiration behind bio-inspired optimizers enables them to thoroughly explore solution spaces, maintaining diversity and preventing premature convergence to suboptimal solutions. This capability for indiscriminate exploration, their versatility, and their ability for parallel execution position them as efficient tools for optimizing ANNi models. Ultimately, the performance of optimizers is juxtaposed with the phenomenon under examination. The simulation process for the CANNi model culminates in scenario generation, a task demanding adherence to conventional practices that must be in line with applicable standards and regulations. Adhering to established norms ensures the credibility and relevance of the generated scenarios. 3.5.1 Test scenario considerations 1 Following the standards set by Passive House [58], three cities were selected to represent different climatic conditions: polar, cold, and temperate. MATLAB® software version 2021b was used for the ANN modeling; the optimization toolbox integrated with the software was used. Several crucial steps were undertaken in the model's development process, with data preprocessing being one of the most significant. The fundamental architecture of the ANN comprised four neurons in the input layer (represented by m f , R s , T wm , T op ) and one in the output layer ( q t ), and the number of neurons in the hidden layer was determined through empirical adjustments during the model development process. The initial set of models explored the impact of varying the number of neurons in the hidden layer from 1 to 5. These models employed conventional transfer functions like LOGSIG, TANSIG, SOFTPLUS, SWISH, and ELU. The maximum limit of five neurons in the hidden layer was selected based on prior research in the field [17]. The second group of models focused on conformable transfer functions (CLOGSIG, CTANSIG, CSOFTPLUS, CSWISH, CELU), with the number of neurons in the hidden layer ranging from 1 to 5. This investigation aimed to assess the performance of these newer transfer functions in addressing the modeling problem. Ten thousand simulations were performed for each of the 50 models generated. The training of the ANN models utilized the Levenberg-Marquardt optimization algorithm. An initial filter was applied using a slope-intercept test with a 99 % confidence level. This filter identified models with robust performance metrics (R, RMSE, MAPE) and those that accurately represented linear relationships between variables. Of the 50 models created, 44 successfully passed the slope-intercept test, with 19 using traditional transfer functions and 25 using conformable transfer functions. Tables 4 and 5 display the results obtained from the classical and conformable models, respectively. These tables include the metrics b Upper and I b Lower , representing the upper and lower approaches of the intercept, m Upper and m Lower indicating the upper and lower slope approaches. Figs. 4, 5, and 6 provide insights into the performance of each model in terms of the assessed metrics, namely R, MAPE, and RMSE. The performance of the ANN models was analyzed about the thermal characteristics of the RFH system. The conformable models demonstrated a superior ability to predict RFH performance, which is reflected in the ability of these models to accurately adjust the operating parameters required to maintain a comfortable temperature. CLOGSIG 4:5:1 and CSWISH 4:5:1, consistently outperform other models, regardless of the number of neurons. Considering the number of neurons in model selection, CTANSIG 4:3:1 emerges as the most balanced option. This model meets high correlation and prediction precision criteria and offers computational efficiency benefits due to its simplified structure. Reducing the number of neurons decreases the computational resources required for training and inference and the risk of overfitting, leading to a more robust generalization of new data. Starting with our best model, we derived an equation describing its behavior by substituting the transfer function, weights, and biases obtained during CANN training into the target function Eq. (2). Then, we simplified it through algebraic factorization to provide a more concise representation, as shown in Eq. (6). Fig. 7 illustrates the effectiveness of the predictive capability of the resulting model, highlighting how it can accurately predict the optimal operating conditions of the RFH system. Showing how these optimizations can significantly improve the thermal performance of the RFH system under various climate scenarios. CANNi was simulated by creating scenarios that reflect typical RFH implementation in various climate zones. The considerations for scenario development were explained in the methodology section Fig. 9 to Fig. 11 present important graphs for Munich, Vancouver, and Murmansk. The “a“ graph illustrates the actual temperature recorded on the coldest day in these cities, while the “b” graph indicates the amount needed to maintain a comfortable temperature of 20 °C. This analysis forms the basis for understanding energy use in cold climates, which is essential for evaluating the effectiveness of optimization techniques. This knowledge allows us to discern the energy required to maintain comfortable indoor conditions and how these demands fluctuate in response to extreme outdoor conditions. The maximum heating load required for each city, as indicated by the peak value of q t ​, corresponds to the lowest recorded outdoor temperature of the year. Table 6 contrasts typical heating load values for each climate type, referenced from the ASHRAE [60], with those derived in this study. The peak heating load is subject to various interrelated factors, which are not exhaustively explored in this analysis. Conventionally, peak heating loads are observed between 5 am and 6 am, coinciding with the lowest outdoor temperatures. However, in our study, the timing of the peak heating load might deviate from this norm. This deviation arises because our analysis primarily focuses on how the radiant floor heating (RFH) system responds to optimized temperature data provided by the POWER tool, rather than adhering to the typical hourly trends of decreasing outdoor temperatures. Fig. 12 to Fig. 14 presents data on the performance of GA and PSO when adjusting T wm . Although the fluid temperatures might appear somewhat low, this contrasts with Figs. 15 to 17 , which show that the adjustments to the operating temperature approach the proposed value of 20 °C, considered as the thermal comfort temperature and the Wall Temperature T wall achieved with the T wm values. In the Munich scenario (see Fig. 15), GA consistently maintains an operating temperature closer to the comfort target of 20 °C (21.5 °C) than PSO (19.9 °C). Additionally, the wall surface temperature T wall remains within the comfortable range of 20 °C to 30 °C. This observation suggests that GA excels in fine-tuning conditions to achieve an optimal thermal environment. Similarly, in the Vancouver scenario (see Fig. 16), GA sustains a slightly higher average operating temperature (21.4 °C) than PSO (19.9 °C), maintaining the T wall in the same range of comfort temperature desired, indicating that GA is more dependable in ensuring thermal comfort, particularly in warmer climates. In the Murmansk scenario (see Fig. 17), GA achieves a notably higher average operating temperature (21.7 °C) than PSO (20 °C), showcasing its capacity to adapt and efficiently respond to more severe climate conditions. Fig. 18 to Fig. 20 directly compare the errors associated with each optimizer's task of adjusting the parameters necessary to attain thermal comfort. In the Munich scenario (see Fig. 18), GA consistently exhibits lower errors throughout the day than PSO, implying greater precision in parameter adjustments for maintaining thermal comfort. Similarly, in the Vancouver scenario (see Fig. 19), error patterns resembling those observed in Munich are evident. GA consistently demonstrates lower errors, underscoring its higher efficiency and reliability in adjusting thermal comfort conditions. Despite Murmansk's icy weather conditions (see Fig. 20), GA maintains a lower error rate than PSO, showcasing its resilience and capacity to deliver accurate adjustments even in demanding environments. Fig. 9 to Fig. 20 illustrate the consistent superiority of GA over PSO across different climatic contexts. GA consistently sustains operational temperatures closer to or higher than the desired threshold and exhibits fewer errors in its execution, signifying enhanced precision and efficiency. These findings underscore the importance of selecting the appropriate optimizer for heat transfer and thermal comfort applications in buildings, especially when addressing substantial climatic variations. 5 Conclusion The study showcases the effectiveness of conformable models by emphasizing their remarkable capacity to establish correlations and reduce errors. These attributes underscore the models' robust capability to tackle the intricacies of thermal comfort. Identifying CTANSIG 4:3:1 as the optimal model underscores a harmonious balance between accuracy and computational efficiency, underscoring its pragmatic utility in temperature-controlled environment modeling. In this context, integrating optimization algorithms (such as GA and PSO) within the framework of CANNi has emerged as a potent strategy for identifying optimal thermal conditions. This approach facilitates comprehensive exploration within the solution space, showcasing the adaptability and responsiveness of these tools to evolving input parameters. Fusing CANNi models with advanced optimization techniques represents an innovative avenue for enhancing the design and performance of RFH. The model's adaptability and robustness are underscored through its simulation across diverse climate zones, including Polar, Cold, and Cold-Temperature regions. Fine-tuning the model to accommodate extreme conditions in locales like Murmansk, Vancouver, and Munich underscores its efficacy in delivering optimal thermal solutions across varied climatic contexts. This versatility underscores the model's pragmatic utility in optimizing RFH and enhancing thermal comfort. This study represents a substantial advancement in thermal engineering and sustainable construction by offering a methodology and tools for the efficient design and optimization of RFH. Integrating CANNi with optimization techniques effectively tackles contemporary challenges in regulating thermal comfort. CRediT authorship contribution statement A.I. coredata.dc:description: This study introduces an innovative methodology that integrates Inverse Conformable Artificial Neural Networks (CANNi) with Genetic Algorithms (GA) or Particle Swarm Optimization (PSO) to optimize thermal comfort in buildings. Emphasizing the efficacy of conformable transfer functions within CANNi, the research relies on a comprehensive dataset to forecast heat transfer across diverse climates. Notably, the methodology stands out for its meticulous model selection process, employing slope-intercept tests to ensure robust predictability (99%) and strong correlation between input and output variables. The selected model exhibits an optimal equilibrium between predictive precision and computational efficiency, reaching an R-value of 0.9992 with low RMSE (0.0078) and MAPE (2.1099). Such performance enables precise calibration of Radiant Floor Heating Systems (RFH) for enhanced comfort and marks a significant stride toward bolstering energy efficiency and sustainability within the construction sector. These findings advocate for more efficient utilization of energy resources in buildings, adeptly accommodating climatic fluctuations and enhancing the inhabitants’ quality of life.
